Articles.Content:
I wondered how much a given engine could lift, so with the help of Kerbal Engineer I was able to calculate, minus the weight of each engine itself, how much they could lift at a 1.00 minimum TWR. I plan to do .625m and smaller engines next, then move on to 2.5m and then 3.75m as well, that is, if you guys are interested ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif)

Here's the first set:

> [Javascript is disabled. View full album](//imgur.com/a/hlaf9)
Thanks! You should do comparisons between 1.25m clusters and 2.5m single engines.
A thing I learn in KSP is you can lift about 0.1 \* thrust in ton (a vessel with 50 kN of thrust can lift about 5t not more, itself+propellant included).

> 
> A thing I learn in KSP is you can lift about 0.1 \* thrust in ton

Specifically with (force in newtons) you can lift (acceleration due to gravity) \* (mass in kg).

Replace newtons with kilonewtons and kg with tons if you prefer, the result is the same ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

IIRC Kerbin has the same 9.81m/s/s of gravity that Earth does. Allowing 10kN/ton will give you just enough thrust to actually move; at 9.81kN/ton you're able to maintain altitude, but no more.

> 
> Thanks! You should do comparisons between 1.25m clusters and 2.5m single engines.

Good idea, I'll try that! It might get kinda complicated, tho... :/

Hey, by the way, I'll post a different thread on this later, but I figured out a really good way to organize your crafts.

You'll notice I had my test rockets named "Experimental - \_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_", well I figured out I could categorize all my crafts this way, with tags like Experimental, Station for station pieces, Lander, Base, etc. Also, I have Recreational and Indev tabs, which, recreational being just kinda like, a roleplay thing or a replica, and Indev is something In Development, so I know where to look when I wanna work on a certain craft. I also went into the save file and disabled stock vessels, they clutter up the list, especially when it's alphabetical.

Hope that helps!

-Slab
For some reason, KER is not accounting for thrust/isp loss at low atmosphere. The LV-30 might go to orbit alone, but I don't think the LV-909 can.
